definition: clever at getting what you want, sometimes by not telling the truth
designed or done in a clever way
a disease that causes one or more joints of the body to become painful and swollen (= larger than normal)
a round vegetable with a lot of thick green leaves. The bottom part of the leaves and the inside of the artichoke can be eaten when cooked.
a light-brown root vegetable that looks like a potato
the clever use of tricks to cheat somebody
the skill of an artist
the position of having power or influence over somebody/something
the act of climbing or moving up; a journey that goes up something
a path or slope that goes up something
the process of moving forward to a better position or of making progress
to find out the true or correct information about something
possible to find out correctly
that has a lot of industries
the end of a play, book, etc., in which everything is explained or settled; the end result of a situation
a person who lives in a simple and strict way, without physical pleasures, especially for religious reasons
not involving sexual activity or feelings; not having sexual qualities
not experiencing sexual attraction or a desire to have sexual relationships
not involving sex; not having sexual organs
feeling shame or feeling embarrassed about somebody/something or because of something you have done
unwilling to do something because of shame or fear of feeling embarrassed
very pale; without colour because of illness or fear
towards, onto or on land, having come from an area of water such as the sea or a river
a container into which people who smoke put ash, cigarette ends, etc.
sleeping
used to describe a part of the body that has no feeling in it, usually because it has been in the same position for too long
not paying enough attention to what you need to do
a small poisonous snake found in south-west Europe
a general name for various types of small poisonous snake found in North Africa
a plant whose young green or white stems are cooked and eaten as a vegetable
either of two areas in the brain that are linked to memory, the emotions and the sense of smell
a member of a group of people who do not live in one place but move around and live by hunting, fishing and gathering plants
a thick black sticky substance used especially for making the surface of roads
the existence of two or more allotropes of a chemical element
to make somebody become unconscious or die by preventing them from breathing
one of the different forms in which a chemical element exists. For example, diamond and graphite are allotropes of carbon.
a soft black mineral that is a form of carbon. Graphite is used to make pencils, to lubricate machines and in nuclear reactors.
a strong desire to have or do something
the action of pronouncing a word with a breath that can be heard, as in the /h/ sound in house in English
a thin board with a hole in it for the thumb to go through, used by an artist for mixing colours on when painting
the colours used by a particular artist
between red and purple in colour
an allotrope (= form) of carbon with molecules of 60 atoms arranged in a round hollow shape
a person who attacks somebody, especially physically
a person who murders somebody important or famous, for money or for political reasons
to work together in order to achieve a particular aim; to organize a group of people to do this
to find and start to use something that is needed for a particular purpose
if a country mobilizes its army, or if a country or army mobilizes, it makes itself ready to fight in a war
a method of finding out distance and position, usually on a map, by measuring the distance between two fixed points and then measuring the angle from each of these to the third point
one of the sharp curved nails on the end of an animal’s or a bird’s foot
a long, sharp curved part of the body of some types of shellfish, used for catching and holding things
part of a tool or machine, like a claw, used for holding, pulling or lifting things
to manage to get into a relationship with somebody in a way that gives you control over them
to criticize somebody severely
involving opposition or competition that is violent and without sympathy
official agreement to or approval of something
to state clearly and definitely that something is true
to behave in a confident and determined way so that other people pay attention to your opinions
to make other people recognize your right or authority to do something, by behaving in a determined and confident way
to start to have an effect
a statement saying that you strongly believe something to be true
the act of stating, using or claiming something strongly
expressing opinions or desires strongly and with confidence, so that people take notice
an opinion or a judgement about somebody/something that has been thought about very carefully
the act of judging or forming an opinion about somebody/something
the process of testing students and making a judgement about their knowledge, ability or progress
an amount that has been calculated and that must be paid
an expert in a particular subject who is asked by a court or other official group to give advice
a person who calculates the value or cost of something or the amount of money to be paid
a person who judges how well somebody has done in an exam, a competition, etc.
